awd_titl_txt: RoL: RAISE: DESYN-C3: Membrane-based cell-free systems for scalable production of plant natural products
awd_abstract_narration:
Making something that works signifies that one understands how it works at a fundamental level and that one can add features to study their effects upon performance.  For example, to a working airplane model one can add a curve to the wings, up-notched wingtips, and a whole host of modifications to see how they affect the performance of the plane. The same design paradigm holds true in biology. If one can make a cell from scratch that works, then one can start adding pieces to it and engineering functions into the system.  This research project aims to create a synthetic cell system that mimics the membrane of a plant cell. Once a functioning system is achieved, different proteins that normally are found in plant cell membranes will be added to the synthetic cell system to determine what functions they display. The researchers will primarily focus on model set of proteins that produce an Alzheimer's drug. To further enhance the impact of the research project, the researchers will also develop new educational material about synthetic cells, train graduate and undergraduate students, and perform outreach to the general public to generate and further understanding about the idea of synthetic cells and their potential uses. 

To date, it has not been possible to create self-assembling, membrane-based cell-free systems. The primary hypothesis of this research project is that success can be achieved through regulated control over the timing and expression levels of enzymes for phospholipid vesicle generation. To achieve this goal, the researchers will integrate a CRISPR-based genetic control system with phospholipid production pathways. Specifically, they will construct a highly-efficient membrane-based gene expression system for plant transmembrane proteins. The intended plant natural product to be synthesized is the Alzheimer's drug, Galantamine. If successful in producing Galantamine, the researchers will expand the system to a variety of other transmembrane proteins, emulating plant cell environments. As a result, this research project will expand cell-free bioengineering capabilities and will provide new methods to prepare synthetic cell systems with complex membrane compositions. These systems will enable scientists to better understand the relationship between membrane biophysics and enzymatic activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The bottom-up development of synthetic cell systems could enable the scalable manufacture of medicines and vaccines, the reliable production of bio-nano materials, and even help address long-standing questions about the origins of life. This project generated foundational knowledge and technologies for using membrane-augmented cell-free expression systems as synthetic cell analogs. Support from this award enabled us to 1) engineer improved cell-free expression systems that can be used to express complex multi-gene pathways, 2) explore routes for expressing functional membrane proteins in membrane-augmented cell-free expression reactions, and 3) develop new classes of deep, wide, and multi-input CRISPR-based genetic circuits that can be used to dynamically control cell-free expression systems. Collectively, these efforts took important steps toward the creation of synthetic cell systems and engineered living materials with capabilities that can be tailored for a wide variety of real-world applications. 

Constructing genetically programmable synthetic cell systems requires intellectual tools and experimental skills from a number of areas, including soft matter physics and nanoscience, molecular biology, chemistry and chemical engineering.  A major aspect of this project was the collaborative development and delivery of new course content on engineering synthetic cell systems for reproducible biomanufacturing.  This project also provided advanced, interdisciplinary training for Ph.D. students, research associates, technicians and undergraduates at the University of Washington, the University of Minnesota and the Georgia Institute of Technology.  The project produced broadly applicable toolkits, quantitative datasheets, and experimentally-validated methods that were made available through a commercial partner and publicly-supported databases and repositories. The research products were disseminated through scientific publications, presentations at international conferences, Engineering Biology Research Consortium meetings, and courses at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2023
Modified by: James Carothers
